EXECUTIVE SUMMARY





Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies



Sunrise Power Company, LLC utilizes anhydrous ammonia in two identical selective catalytic reduction (SCR) processes for the two gas turbines at their power plant near Fellows, California.  Since each SCR process handles more than 10,000 pounds of anhydrous ammonia, Sunrise Power Company, LLC has developed and implemented a process safety management (PSM) program for the SCR processes.  



As part of the PSM program, Sunrise Power Company, LLC has completed process hazard analyses, developed written operating procedures, trained employees on the SCR processes, conducted a pre-startup safety review, and developed a mechanical integrity program for the ammonia equipment.  In addition to plant personnel monitoring the operation of the SCR processes on a daily basis, Sunrise Power Company, LLC has implemented a preventative maintenance program to ensure that the SCR processes are maintained in good operating condition.  Properly maintained equipment reduces the risk of an accidental release.



Sunrise Power Company, LLC emphasizes safe and environmentally sound operating practices and procedures through their employee training programs.  In addition to job specific and process specific training, operators and maintenance personnel receive training in fire prevention, fire control, accident prevention, safety, and first aid.  



While it is Sunrise Power Company, LLC's objective to be a responsible citizen of the community in all of its business activities, the limited staff at the power plant precludes emergency response operations.  As such, an Emergency Action Plan has been prepared for the Sunrise Power Company, LLC facility and a chain of command to respond to emergencies has been established.



Sunrise Power Company, LLC is independently audited to evaluate compliance with the PSM and RMP regulations.  At least every three years, Sunrise Power Company, LLC will audit these p

rograms and any findings of noncompliance will be documented and responded to and the deficiencies will be corrected.



Description of the Stationary Source and Regulated Substances 



The Sunrise Power Company, LLC facility is located on approximately 16 acres in Section 23, T31S/R22E, MDB&M in the sparsely populated Midway-Sunset oil field.  The plant is located approximately 3 miles northwest of the community of Fellows, 2.5 miles south of Derby Acres, and 1.3 miles west of Highway 33.  



The Sunrise Power Company, LLC power plant produced commercial power for the first time on June 26, 2001 configured as a 320 megawatt simple cycle peaker plant.  Two natural gas fired General Electric Frame 7FA turbines physically coupled to electric generators provided the power during the peak demand period of the California energy crisis in the summer of 2001.  



In December 2001, construction began on an expansion of the facility that would convert the simple cycle 320 megawatt peaker plant into a 585 megawatt combined cycle power plant.  The "Phase II" expansion included installation of two duct-fired heat recovery steam generators (HSRG) and a 265 megawatt steam turbine generator.  To help control the nitrogen oxide emissions from the gas turbine, each HRSG is equipped with an anhydrous ammonia-based selective catalytic reduction (SCR) system.  



In the SCR process, anhydrous ammonia vapors from the storage tank are injected into the high temperature turbine exhaust ahead of the catalytic reactor.  The high temperature of the exhaust causes the ammonia to dissociate and create a reducing atmosphere before the flue gas enters the catalytic reactor.  This reducing atmosphere in the turbine flue gas helps convert nitrogen oxides to nitrogen and water as the flue gas passes through the catalytic reactor.  The operation of the SCR system substantially lowers the emissions of nitrogen oxides from the gas turbine.



The SCR systems at the Sunrise Power Company, LLC facil

ity are identical.  Anhydrous ammonia is stored in two 5,300 gallon (water capacity) storage tanks.  The maximum intended inventory of each anhydrous ammonia storage tank is physically limited to approximately 4,500 gallons through the installation of a overflow stand pipe inside each tank.  The overflow stand pipe is installed on the ammonia delivery vapor return line and limits the capacity of the tank to approximately 85 percent.  If the ammonia delivery truck operator fills the storage tank above 85 percent capacity, the excess ammonia is returned to the delivery truck through the vapor line.  Additionally, each tank is equipped with a level transmitter that will close emergency shutoff valves on the ammonia delivery lines if the tank level exceeds 85 percent.  Limiting the capacity of the anhydrous ammonia storage tank to 85 percent establishes a maximum storage capacity of approximately 22,636 pounds.



For purposes of the offsite consequence analyses, 40 CFR Part 68 defines the toxic endpoint for anhydrous ammonia as 0.14 mg/l (200 ppm).



General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps



A PSM program, which meets the requirements of the general accidental release prevention program, is being implemented at Sunrise Power Company, LLC to address the anhydrous ammonia system.  The PSM program includes the following chemical-specific prevention steps:



- Written process safety information, including information pertaining to the hazards of ammonia, the technology of the process, and the equipment in the process has been compiled.



- Process Hazard Analyses (PHA) have been completed and will be updated and revalidated at least every five years.



- Written operating procedures have been developed and will be reviewed at least annually.



- Safe work practices, such as lockout/tagout, confined space entry, opening process equipment or piping, and control over entrance into the facility have been developed and implemen

ted.



- Each employee involved in operating the ammonia system has received initial training and refresher training at least every three years.



- Written mechanical integrity procedures have been established and implemented.



- A Management of Change (MOC) program has been developed and implemented to address all proposed changes to the ammonia system.



- Pre-startup safety reviews will be performed when a modification is made to the ammonia system that is significant enough to require a change in the process safety information.



- Audits will be conducted at least every three years to evaluate compliance with the RMP regulations.



- Incident investigation procedures have been established.



- A written plan of action regarding the implementation of employee participation has been developed and implemented.



- Hot work permits will be issued for all hot work operations conducted on or near the ammonia system.



- A Contractor Safety Policy has been developed and implemented.



To ensure that the general accidental release prevention program and the chemical-specific prevention steps are implemented, Sunrise Power Company, LLC has assigned overall responsibility for the RMP elements to the Plant Manager.  The Plant Manager has the overall responsibility for the development, implementation, and integration of the RMP elements.



Five-Year Accident History



Sunrise Power Company, LLC began commercial operation of the power plant in June 2001 and commissioned the ammonia based SCR process in the spring of 2003.  The Sunrise Power Company, LLC facility has not had any accidental releases that have resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.



Emergency Response Program



Sunrise Power Company, LLC has established an emergency action plan and a chain of command to respond to emergencies and to notify emergency resp

onders when there is a need for a response.  However, an emergency response program does not need to be developed for the facility since Sunrise Power Company, LLC employees will not respond to accidental releases of ammonia, the facility is included in the community emergency response plan, and appropriate mechanisms are in place to notify emergency responders.  



Planned Changes To Improve Safety



Through the accidental release prevention program, Sunrise Power Company, LLC regularly evaluates the need for any changes to improve safety.  Currently, Sunrise Power Company, LLC does not have any changes to the anhydrous ammonia-based SCR processes planned to improve safety.
